In principle, this omitted absorption could systematically increase the radiative forcing by CH 4. Over 64% (
14 ) of solar insolation occurs at wave numbers ν > 11,000 cm −1, and hence there is 1.78 times more energy to absorb in this portion of the solar spectrum than at ν ≤ 11,000 cm −1. In addition, several processes including greater Rayleigh scattering (
15 ,
16 ) and higher cloud and land surface albedos (
17 ,
18 ) act to increase path lengths traversed by photons with ν > 11,000 cm −1 relative to longer wavelengths. The resulting increase in tropospheric absorption path lengths from increased atmospheric and surface scattering (
19 ,
20 ) at ν > 11,000 cm −1 reduces the flux of upwelling diffuse solar radiation at the tropopause, thereby potentially increasing the net direct radiative forcing by methane.
